Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence provided to show that US students actually sang the Indian national anthem to thank India for supplying hydroxychloroquine.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the video of US students singing the Indian national anthem is related to the supply of hydroxychloroquine by India, but there is no direct connection or evidence provided to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the video was originally published in 2017, unrelated to the current COVID-19 pandemic and the supply of hydroxychloroquine.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of the video by implying that it is a recent response to the supply of hydroxychloroquine, when in fact it is a pre-existing video from 2017.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the provided claim.
Falters at times: There is no evidence of a faltering bias in the provided claim.
Exist alternative explanation: There is no evidence of alternative explanation bias in the provided claim.
